Another more recent laughter theory, a bit like Incongruity Theory, is Benign Violation theory. Basically, something violates expectations, norms, or otherwise just isn't "right" or "what should be the case" (similar to the surprise element of Incongruity Theory). Then, if that occurs in a benign/non-threatening fashion, then that creates laughter.
E.g. your friend slipping, falling and spilling ping pong balls is a violation (surprise/unexpected/abnormal), but if they're fine, then it's a benign violation. If they're actually hurt, it's less funny (especially to them) because it's less benign. Another example would be your dad (benign) tickling you (violation) versus a stranger in a trench coat (threatening) doing it.
What constitutes a violation, as well as the line between benign or not, will vary greatly by person. This may explain why much of comedy is so subjective - a joke that one person finds hilarious might be boring to another (because they find it predictable/nothing unusual), and a third person might find it disturbing, depressing or even offensive (because they don't find it benign).

I've suffered from sinusitis for a long time and I recently stumbled on something that really really helps: buzzing my lips! Buzzing them at a very low frequency and very loudly causes my head (and nose) to vibrate and all the stuff in it. Sometimes, I can even make myself sneeze if I do it right. Anyway, after about 15-20 minutes or so, I can feel the mucus moving around down my throat and eustachian tubes. Since I started doing it, my sinusitis has steadily improved and I haven't had ear infections.

How is that useful from an evolutionary standpoint? Most people don’t feel the mosquito in the act of biting, only later, when the body’s inflammatory response and allergic reaction kicks in so scratching away an insect isn’t very common. I’m just asking because my dermatologist always says don’t scratch when I get bit by bugs, develop a rash or hives, have pimples or dry skin.

At one point, every now and then, I would start laughing at something but become completely unable to stop. I would try to talk and ask people to help me while also laughing hysterically. Needless to say, it was really confusing to everyone. It felt really weird and scary because I had absolutely no control. I thought I was having a seizure, or something.

Never found out what it was, but it was probably a side effect to one of the many new meds I was already on or trying, at the time.

Uncontrollable yawning, mini eye seizures, and being easily startled were a couple other really odd side effects to prescription drugs that I've experienced.

Maybe laughing to something that is not congruent with what is expected is something social animals get rewarded with pleasure because it alerts others to pay attention. Maybe if someone falls, and you are not closely related to that other one so you don't care about them or you even hate them, if you laugh at them maybe that makes the ones related to them aware of the problem and try to assist. Your laughter may be then a way of altruism that doesn't require you to be altruistic, but is even forced on your by that incontrollable reaction.

It works also to call the attention of others who can assist in an stressful situation you can not handle.
